items.content_text:
Countdown clocks, zines, and an imagined website from 2001 (Interconnected)

There’s a website from 2001 for making zines with your friends that, at this point, only exists in my head, if it ever existed honestly, but I wish it were in the world, because in this age of WhatsApp and Slack and whatever, we need it

I love Matt Webb’s idea for a collaborative web zine with a defined publishing schedule. The first website we built, way back in the 90s, followed that model complete with issues and deadlines. It didn’t need to, but we were coming from the world of print and hadn’t yet learned to produce any other way.

items.title: Kinder To Do Lists
items.content_html:
Absolutely loved this piece by Beck Tench about the language we use in our To Do lists:

For those of us that use digital tools to manage our to do lists, it is especially important to consider how we use language in creating to do items. When items start with verbs (e.g. Use, Soak, Cook, Combine, Check, Cook, Eat), they become commands. This results in computers commanding us to do things. They control our time and our agency in subtle (and sometimes overt) ways.

Kinder To Do Lists — I am Beck Tench

items.title: The Cappella Palatina
items.content_html: The Capella Palatina in Palermo’s Royal Palace is one of the most amazing buildings I have ever been inside. It is entirely decorated with intricate gold mosaics, enveloping visitors in an ethereal glow.It was commissioned by the Norman king Roger II and completed in the mid 12th century. The architectural styles are a fascinating blend of east meets west, a Christian nave with Arabic arches and a Byzantine dome. But really, it’s all about the mosaics.You can read more about it on Wikipedia or just jump on a flight now and you’ll be there in time for lunch at Bisso Bistrot on the Quattro Canti.
items.content_text:
The Capella Palatina in Palermo’s Royal Palace is one of the most amazing buildings I have ever been inside. It is entirely decorated with intricate gold mosaics, enveloping visitors in an ethereal glow.

It was commissioned by the Norman king Roger II and completed in the mid 12th century. The architectural styles are a fascinating blend of east meets west, a Christian nave with Arabic arches and a Byzantine dome. But really, it’s all about the mosaics.

You can read more about it [on Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cappella_Palatina) or just jump on a flight now and you’ll be there in time for lunch at Bisso Bistrot on the Quattro Canti.
